params.text:
SECTION 01

Ask an Interesting Question
Supervised Learning - Medicine

Machine learning algorithms can indeed function as a magic box that can perform the task without any theoretical rules. However, they can do much better if they are built with the domain knowledge in mind.
Introduction: Warfarin Dose Prediction Models

• The objective of this tutorial is to guide you to build and analyse a machine learning-based warfarin dose prediction models using scikit-learn. Warfarin is a commonly used anticoagulant that is used to prevent blood clots.
  • The model developed here should NOT be used by doctors and patients to make treatment decisions as they are purely research and educational resources.

This project is based on the following article tutorial: Ahn, S. “Building and Analyzing Machine Learning-Based Warfarin Dose Prediction Models Using Scikit-Learn.” Translational and Clinical Pharmacology 30, no. 4 (2022): 172–81. https://doi.org/10.12793/tcp.2022.30.e22.

SECTION 02

Get the Data & Explore
Supervised Learning - Medicine

Now that we have an interesting question to investigate, we will now search for the data to learn from. In this chapter, you will learn how to import data from an external source to Orange and to explore them to design your next steps.
Reading 2: PharmGKB Database

We will collect our data from the PharmGKB database (Pharmacogenomics Knowledgebase), which is maintained by researchers at Stanford University.

The project collects and curates information about genetic variants and their effects on drug response, drug annotations, phamacokinetic pathways, and many other related to drugs and our response to them.

Their database can be accessed through: https://www.pharmgkb.org/

Instructions 01:

Select “File” widget from “Data” tab and add it to the canvas.

Activity 2-1: Importing the Data

In this acitivity, we will download our data from International Warfarin Pharmacogenetics Consortium (IWPC), curated by PharmGKB and the members of the consortium.

Instructions 02:

Double click on the ‘File’ widget to open its settings. Copy the following URL to the Source and Orange will import the file from the website: 

https://raw.githubusercontent.com/ENKISProjekt/

H5P-Hosting/main/dataset/Medicine/IWPC_cleaned.csv

Instructions 03:

By clicking on the data icon with the number ‘3345’ on the bottom-left corner, you can open a new window where you can explore the data in detail. Take a moment to observe how the data look like.

SECTION 03

Explore the Data
Supervised Learning - Medicine

There are a lot of features in the data that we just downloaded to Orange. Which genotypes/phenotypes can we use to predict the dose of Warfarin? We will first use a statistical measure called 'correlation' to see which features are most 'correlated' to adequate level warfarin dose determined by doctors.
Reading 3: Correlation

Correlation is a statistical measure that tells us how two sets of data are related to each other. Imagine you have two sets of numbers, like the amount of studying you do and your test scores. Correlation helps us see if there's a connection between them.

If they have a positive correlation, it means that as one set of numbers goes up, the other tends to go up too. For example, if you study more, your test scores might also go up.

If they have a negative correlation, it means that as one set of numbers goes up, the other tends to go down. For instance, if you spend more time watching TV, your test scores might decrease.

And if there's no correlation, it means there's no clear relationship between the two sets of data. So correlation helps us understand how changes in one thing might relate to changes in another thing.
Questions 3: Correlation

choices.question: What does a correlation coefficient of -0.9 between two variables indicate?
answers:
There is a strong negative relationship between the variables.

There is a weak negative relationship between the variables.

There is a strong positive relationship between the variables.

There is no relationship between the variables.

choices.question: Which statistical measure assesses the strength and direction of the linear relationship between two variables?
What statistical method is used to determine how closely two sets of data are related to each other?

overallFeedback.feedback: Not bad.. but you can do better.

l10n.a11yShowSolution: Show the solution. The task will be marked with its correct solution.
l10n.a11yRetry: Retry the task. Reset all responses and start the task over again.

params.text:
Instructions 01:

We will add the correlations widget from 'unsupervised' tab and link it to the file widget.

Activity 3: Exploring Correlations

In this acitivity, we will calculate the correlation between prescribed warfarin dose and each of all other vectors.

Instructions 02:

Double click on the Correlation widget to open a new window. As we are only interested in pairs with Warfarin dose, select Warfarin instead of (All Combinations). VKORC1 should be the feature that is the most correlated to Warfarin.

As an extra piece of information, VKORC1 is the gene that encodes Vitamine K epoxide Reductase Complex subunit 1 and is known to play a central role in warfarin metabolism.

SECTION 04

Model the Data
Supervised Learning - Medicine
We have figured out that VKORC1 is the most correlated to Warfarin, but there are also other features that are somewhat strongly correlated. Can we use all of them together to predict warfarin dose?
Reading 4: Regression

Regression analysis is a statistical method used to understand the relationship between one dependent variable and one or more independent variables.

In single regression, we're looking at the relationship between one dependent variable and one independent variable. For example, if we're trying to predict someone's weight (dependent variable) based on their height (independent variable), we'd use single regression. It helps us understand how changes in one variable (height) might affect changes in another variable (weight). In multiple regression, we will use multiple dependent variables and linearly combine them to predict the independent variable.
Questions 4: Regression

choices.question: Which statistical method is used to predict one variable based on the values of another variable (or variables)?
Which statistical technique is used to predict a dependent variable based on one independent variable in a simple model?
answers:
Single regression analysis

Correlation analysis

Multiple regression analysis

Variance analysis

overallFeedback.feedback: Not bad.. but you can do better.

l10n.a11yRetry: Retry the task. Reset all responses and start the task over again.

params.text:
Instructions 01:

We will first use "Select Columns" widget from Transform tab to select Warfarin as our target of prediction.

Activity 4: Linear Regression

In this acitivity, we will create a regression model to predict Warfarin from other features.

Instructions 02:

Double click on the select columns widget to open a new window. We will predcit Warfarin from other features, so select Warfarin and click on the arrow icon to move it to target.

Instructions 03:

We will now split the data into two sets: the train dataset to train our model and the test dataset to test the model. It is important that the model does not 'see' the train dataset, as this may strongly favor overfitted models.

Add a Data Sampler widget from the Transform Tab and link it to the Select Column widget.

Instructions 04:

Double clicking on the Data Sampler widget can open a window where you can further specify parameters for the widget. However, we will leave it as the default setting for now.

Instructions 05:

Add a "Linear Regression" widget from Model tab and link it to the Data Sampler widget. The link should say: "Data Sample" to "Data", as the sampled train data should be supplied to the model for learning.

Instructions 06:

Then, we will use the trained model to make predictions for the test data and check how good the predictions are. Add a Predictions widget from Evaluate tab and link it to the Linear Regression model AND the Data Sampler widget.

Instructions 07:

Note that the Data Sampler widget should supply the 'Remaining Data' as 'Data' to the Predictions widget. Double clicking on the black line connecting the two widget will open a new window where you can specify this.

Instructions 08:

Double clicking on the Predictions window will open a new window where you can explore the model's predictions and some evaluation metrics that describe how good the predictions were.

We will explore the metrics in detail later.

Instructions 09:

To visualize our predictions, we will add a Scatter Plot widget from Visualize tab. Link it to the Predictions widget.

Instructions 10:

Double click on the Scatter Plot widget and select 'Linear Regression' for x axis and 'Warfarin' for y axis. The variable linear regression is a linear combination of all other features that the model generated in order to create a new feature that is the most strongly correlated to warfarin. 

Here, we could see that the data points are roughly aligned to a straight line, which is called the regression line.

SECTION 05

Communicate the Results
Supervised Learning - Medicine

Congratulations on building your Regression model! We could see that the predictions were indeed acceptable through scatter plots, but how good are these predictions? To communicate the performance of your model, we need to know the metrics to evalute the model.
Reading 5: Evaluation Metrics

Here are some metrics that Orange supports to evalute a model.

  • MSE (Mean Squared Error): The average of the squares of the differences between the predicted and actual values, measuring the model's prediction accuracy. A lower MSE indicates a better fit.

  • RMSE (Root Mean Squared Error): The square root of the mean squared error, providing a measure of prediction error in the same units as the original data. A lower RMSE indicates a better fit.

  • MAE (Mean Absolute Error): The average of the absolute differences between predicted and actual values, representing the average magnitude of errors without considering their direction. A lower MAE indicates a better fit.

  • MAPE (Mean Absolute Percentage Error): The average of the absolute percentage differences between predicted and actual values, indicating the prediction accuracy as a percentage. A lower MAPE indicates a better fit.

  • R² (R-squared): The proportion of the variance in the dependent variable that is predictable from the independent variables, showing how well the model explains the data. A higher R² indicates a better fit, with 1 being a perfect fit.

Instructions 01:

Double clicking on the prediction widget will give us such evaluation metrics. Researchers use multiple metrics when sharing their results as each metric evaluates a different aspect of the model and its ability to predict.

Activity 5: Evaluating the Model

After making predictions, we can use them to evaluate our model. Orange gives such information directly from the "Predictions" widget.
Questions 5: Evaluating the Model

choices.question: What does a lower Mean Squared Error (MSE) indicate about a model's performance?
answers:
The model's predictions are more accurate

The model's predictions are less accurate

The model has a higher variance

The model has more bias

choices.question: Which of the following is true about Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE)?
answers:
It measures prediction error in the same units as the original data

It is the square of the mean squared error

A higher RMSE indicates a better model fit

It ignores the direction of errors

choices.question: What does a lower Mean Absolute Error (MAE) signify?
answers:
The model's predictions are more accurate on average

The model is overfitting the data

The model has a higher percentage error

The average prediction error is large

choices.question: Which metric expresses prediction accuracy as a percentage?
What does a higher R² value indicate?
answers:
The model explains more of the variance in the dependent variable

The model explains less of the variance in the dependent variable

The model has higher mean absolute error

The model has higher root mean squared error

overallFeedback.feedback: Not bad.. but you can do better.
